title: What is the best way to write an argumentative essay? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah, a question for writing instructors. That’s me! Who knows, if you’re going to an online university, I might be your professor! At any rate, I’ve been teaching composition and argumentative writing for a solid 15 years, so this should be helpful if it’s not overwhelming. To start, this is too general a question—what you need to do depends heavily on what the assignment or project requires. I’ll try to take that into account as I answer, though. So, Step 1: Read your assignment/project instructions, very VERY carefully. Make sure you understand the main objective of the assignment/project, identify any questions you’re required to answer or ideas you’re required to respond to. Look at formatting requirements—MLA? APA? Chicago style?—and make sure that you understand how many sources you’re required to use, as well as what kind of sources you’re expected to use. Step 2: figure out what overall point you want to make in your essay. An argumentative essay needs to have a claim for a thesis, that is, a declarative statement that takes a specific stance on some kind of debate. So identify the debate you’re addressing, and then figure out what your stance is. This should just be a working thesis at this point; stay flexible on it, as there’s a chance it will change as you do your research. Step 3: assemble your data/evidence. What exactly you look for here will vary depending on the topic you’re writing on. If you’re writing on current events, look for data—statistics from reliable, unbiased sources that give information about what actually is happening—and expert analysis of that data and the larger cultural context. If you’re writing on literature, by contrast, your main evidence needs to come from the work(s) you’re writing on (this is called close reading; you point out parts of the text that are catching your attention, and explain why they’re doing so as it relates to your overall thesis). Step 4: see if the evidence you’ve found fits your working thesis. If it does, great. If it doesn’t, revise your thesis until it works with the evidence you have. Sometimes, you will find that the evidence actually leads you to the conclusion that the opposing argument is stronger; that can be a weird moment, but trust it. Don’t let confirmation bias confine you to a weak stance on an issue/debate. Step 5: decide how to make your argument. This, again, requires checking the instructions/requirements and/or considering your overall goal—how you make the argument (whether you’re trying to just win the logic contest, trying to persuade a neutral audience, trying to persuade a hostile audience, etc.) will often be tied to what you’ve been asked to do in the project/assignment. You also need to figure out what your audience’s level of knowledge is likely to be; you will use different language and terminology when writing for a specialist audience than you would when writing for a general audience. Step 6: Draft the essay. What you do here depends on how you work. Some people do better just drafting it all out at once and then revising once they have most of what they need, while some do better at creating an outline (in which they write out the thesis and the supporting points that need to be made to make the case for that thesis) and then drafting. Figure out what works for you, and do that. Step 7: Review and revise. This can be a tricky step, and it’s really best to let it rest for a day (or at least a few hours) after you complete the draft. Most of us revise more effectively when we come at our drafts with fresh eyes. This can also be a good point to bring in a second reader—observant friend or family member, a tutor—to help you figure out what is and isn’t working, what gaps there are in your logic, etc. Do make sure that this is all right with your instructor if you’re writing for a class. Things to remember in this step: your main goal, as a write, should be clarity. You’re writing for other people, remember, not just for yourself, so you need to make sure that you’ve laid ideas and claims out in a way that others can follow. This means bringing in specific evidence (not big huge chunks of quotation) and fully analyzing that evidence for your readers (tell them what is important about the evidence and how that ties into your overall point); using clear topic sentences that help readers to identify the main point of every paragraph; making sure that every paragraph’s topic leads logically to the topic of the next paragraph, and that you have transition sentences to help readers see those logical chains; and giving clear overviews in the introduction paragraph and concluding paragraph that either introduce readers to the basic skeleton of your argument, or help them review that basic skeleton. Step 8: proofread and edit. This is the very last step before submitting the essay because all the previous steps can change up your writing enough that you might actually revise out entire passages. Since you don’t want to waste time polishing up writing you don’t keep, don’t do the editing until last. Again, this is a place where having a second pair of eyes can really help. Hopefully that’s helpful, and not just overwhelming! This is a pretty big question, so it needs a big answer.

An argumentative essay can be organized using the following sections: Introduction, 3 Body Sections, and Conclusion. Generally, your Introduction is structured as follows: Provide a “hook” such as a compelling, brief anecdote (story), a rhetorical question, or a startling fact. Offer background information about the issue at hand. Present your thesis statement, generally near the end of your Introduction. Remember that the thesis statement is an opinion that you are going to support throughout the rest of the essay. Different terms exist for talking about the opinions you present in an essay; I will use the term “major claim” to refer to your thesis statement and “minor claims” to refer to the reasons for your major claim. For example, let’s say your major claim (your thesis statement) is: “People should not drive cars.” Your three minor claims (reasons) could be: 1)Vehicle emissions are bad for the environment, 2)Car accidents are common, and 3)Driving a vehicle prevents a person from getting exercise by walking or riding a bike. In your 3 Body Sections, you will explain each minor claim in turn, one minor claim per section. Integrate rhetorical appeals such as logos, ethos, and pathos. Logos refers to logic. We all have a need for things to “make sense” logically. Using facts and statistics can help your audience connect the dots and agree with your minor claim. Ethos refers to your credibility as a writer. As you cite your sources using a citation guide such as MLA, APA, or another style guide your instructor (or employer) has provided, you show your reader that you are a credible voice in the conversation regarding a particular issue. Pathos refers to emotion. Discussing a personal vignette about how the issue affected you or someone you know can raise emotions in your reader such as sadness or sympathy, which can lead them to ultimately agree with your major claim. You should also acknowledge and respond to opposing voices. If you can find a source that disagrees with you about one of your minor claims, you should present their objections in a civil manner. Respond to their concerns. If you can easily or with a little research find objections to a minor claim, you should address them in your essay. Certainly, if objections are substantial, you may want to rethink your minor claim. This discussion should typically go in your 3 Body Sections unless otherwise instructed by your teacher or employer. The Conclusion section presents your thesis statement again, invites readers to action, and provides a compelling final thought. Remember to cite all your sources in a Works Cited page separate from your essay. Good luck!

A good introduction in an argumentative essay acts like a good opening statement in a trial. Just like a lawyer, a writer must present the issue at hand, give background, and put forth the main argument -- all in a logical, intellectual and persuasive way. Start With a Hook Start your introduction with a sentence that gets the reader interested in the topic. To pique the reader's interest, you can begin with a quote, a personal story, a surprising statistic or an interesting question. For example, if you are arguing that smoking should be banned from all public places, you can start your introduction by referencing a statistic from a verified source: "Tobacco use kills more than five million people every year -- more than HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria combined, according to the World Health Organization." This strategy grabs the reader's attention while introducing the topic of the essay. Include Background Providing readers with background on the topic allows them to better understand the issue being presented. This information provides context and history that can be crucial to explaining and arguing your point. For example, if you are arguing that there should never be a military draft in the United States, your introduction can include information about the history of the U.S. draft and the events that led to it being abolished. State Your Thesis The thesis is the essence of an argumentative essay. In a single, clear sentence, it sums up what point you are trying to make. The thesis statement should assert a position on a particular issue -- one that a reader can potentially argue against. Therefore, the thesis cannot be a fact. For example, if a professor assigns the general topic of war, you can formulate the following thesis statement: "The United Nations must be redesigned because it is currently incapable of preventing wars." The rest of your essay serves to explain and provide evidence in support of your thesis statement. What to Leave Out A good introduction should not be describing arguments or providing analysis that belong in the body paragraphs. Your introduction should introduce and set up your point, rather than lay out evidence to support it. Also, while your intro is a road map for the rest of the essay, you shouldn't explicitly announce what and how you will be arguing: "I am going to prove to you that ..." This type of set up does not add any pertinent information and only serves as filler. You can check this article here, which is written by our professor.

I’ve written answers to a variation of this question quite a few times, so I hope you’ll look at related questions to get input from a variety of respondents. In those other responses, I’ve gone through the mechanics of structure, types of persuasion, use of rhetorical devices, means of researching and selecting what you’ll include, as well as the common advice to spend about 40% of your effort reviewing, refining, and proofreading your essay. What, then, makes a persuasive essay “outstanding.” (I’m not a fan of the term “argumentative” because it implies that your primary purpose is to be difficult or oppositional. The “arguments” you develop should have the purpose of persuading, which is a more demanding task by far than simply arguing.) Understanding your audience: Who do you need to persuade that your thesis is valid and your argument is convincing in demonstrating that validity?What are their existing beliefs?What kind of evidence persuades them (appeal to emotions, appeal to data, appeal to the authority and expertise of those cited… or of the writer)?What kinds of counter-arguments might they propose?What is their level of knowledge about the topic?What might be their prejudices wrt any evidence/argument you might present (e.g., cited experts that the audience might not trust)?Using solid information: Research is your friend. Before you make a claim that you’re sure is true, verify that with an open mind. It’s crucial not to overstate your case and to know that you have accurate information that you can back up with a citation.Be sure that any expert opinions you present are from someone who is truly an expert in the subject matter related to your essay. Does the information come from a reputable source (e.g., a NASA astrophysicist on space travel, an art historian on cubism, an experienced educator with a degree in education on pedagogical methods)?Recognize the difference between opinions and facts when applying content that someone else has written. This goes both ways. There are people who claim that facts are “just opinions” when they are actually facts. (Often this happens when the naysayer knows little or nothing about the data/evidence/analysis methods but wants to believe something other than what the data/evidence/etc. clearly demonstrates. If such people are your target readers, good luck!) The flip side is for you to be careful that you do not take opinions for facts. If the writer or speaker states an opinion without convincing (accurate, factual) information and solid reasoning, that person is not a good source for your essay.Knowing your audience, make a deliberate decision about how you will present your arguments so that it is easy for the audience to read without becoming defensive; you want them to “listen” to your argument with as much of an open mind as possible. Apply all the fundamentals of writing persuasive essays, using the classical rhetoric of sound reasoning— avoiding at all costs the use of rhetorical/logical fallacies. (If you don’t know about these, you can find the information in places like Purdue University’s OWL writing website.)

Philosophers talk about what constitues a good argument:  Valid logicTrue premisesPremises that are more plausible then their negativesSo, essentially, insofar you have all the three things above, you got yourself a good argument. Now how do you get those?   Valid logic means essentially "premises that folow logically one from each other till reach the conclusion"¹. An argumentative essay is a writing piece meant to persuade someone to think the way you do. Though it's usually organized as an essay. There are some specific elements that are needed in an argumentative essay. The first and most important element in a persuasive essay is the position, or what side the author is on. The purpose of this type of essay is to fully investigate an issue or topic. This involves extensive research covering all aspects of the topic and gathering information on all involved points of view. The main reason someone chooses to write an argumentative essay (other than the fact that their professor told them to!) is to attempt to sway another person or group of people in their opinion on a subject. Pick an issue that is interesting to you. You'll be spending a lot of time researching and writing this paper. So it is important for you to choose a topic that you find interesting from the start. Find a peer (preferably one that holds an oppositional view) to discuss your argument with. This process will help you refine your thinking and develop new ideas to support your judgment. An important aspect of writing an argumentative essay is understanding your audience. It is essential that you understand all of the factors in the situation surrounding your issue. All rhetorical situations contain five basic elements: the text (in your case, the essay), the author (in this case, you), the audience, the purpose or purposes of the communication, and the setting. Create a catchy title. Come up with a thesis statement. Your thesis statement will be a concise idea that sums up your view on the issue. Write an introduction. Write the body of the paper. Carefully present information that supports both your argument and opposition. Write a conclusion. Collect details from custom essay writing service and read the samples.

The thesis is the essence of an argumentative essay. ...What to Leave Out.Do the ResearchOnly choose a topic you are passionate about – you’ll have more fun finding the facts and smashing the other side.No emotions on your part. Now, this does not mean that you can’t stir some emotions in your readers, but you have to do it subtly, by presenting facts that will make them respond emotionally. So, be sure you have some facts that will do that.Don’t slam the other side with dis-respectful terms such as “stupid,” “uninformed,” “evil,” or “crazy.” You may be able to show this with your evidence, but don’t call it out. “What is your strategy on writing an argumentative essay?” Above all, be intellectually honest. Appeal to evidence and logic. Don’t fudge your evidence or employ dishonest arguments to make a rhetorical point — that’s disrespectful to your audience. It’s not enough that your assertions be plausible or convincing, they must be true to the best of your ability to discern the truth. Cite evidence from trustworthy sources. Use primary sources when possible. Don’t regurgitate talking points. Learn the common formal and informal fallacies and resolve to never use them. Do not misrepresent anything. As a lawyer, there’s nothing I like better than being able to tell the court my opponent has misrepresented the facts or the law. (On this point, see my answer to When researching, do lawyers read through all of the relevant cases that might be a precedent?) Don’t insult the intelligence of your readers by resorting to strawman arguments. You’ll only fool the ignorant. Everyone else will conclude you’re not to be trusted. Be honest when discussing the other side’s arguments. Don’t just say they’re wrong, explain why they are, objectively. Where the other side’s arguments have genuine merits, acknowledge them. Defang those arguments, but do so honestly — point out they might not be applicable in this situation, for instance. Tailor your argument to your audience if you can, but that is not a license to pander to your audience’s prejudices. Strive to develop a reputation for intellectual honesty. This may not seem important on a school assignment, but it really does matter whether you make a living with argumentative writing or just want to be respected on Quora.

The best strategy for any essay is to know your audience, and tailor your essay to suit their tastes. If your audience is, say, a middle-aged male teacher, then you should have that in mind while writing the essay. Don’t write it like you would an essay to someone your own age or a friend. What does your audience care about? Make sure their concerns are addressed. Younger people tend to care more about things like freedom and equality. Older people tend to care more about things like safety and stability. If you were one of my students and were arguing for, say, allowing students to leave school for lunch, the freedom argument wouldn’t work on me. I don’t give a damn about how free students feel. I care about their safety. You’d want to address that concern first. The next strategy for an argumentative essay is just like live debating: take away your opponent’s argument before they even make it. You should know both sides of the issue you’re arguing about. Pick your side, state your best argument for your side, then explain why the best argument for the other side is wrong. That’s the step many people forget. Here’s an example of that kind of “pre-rebuttal” tactic: Matthew Bates' answer to Why is school choice generally opposed by liberals?

Understand the purpose of an argumentative essay. The purpose of this type of essay is to fully investigate an issue or topic. This involves extensive research covering all aspects of the topic and gathering information on all involved points of view. Understand the methodology of an argumentative essay. To prepare yourself to write an argumentative essay, it is crucial for you to fully immerse yourself in the subject material. Understand the desired outcome of an argumentative essay. In the end, the main reason someone chooses to write an argumentative essay is to attempt to sway another person or group of people in their opinion on a subject. Selecting a Topic Choose something that fits the format. Remember that an argumentative essay will argue in support of a particular view in a debatable issue. As such, it is important that you do not choose a topic that is not arguable.Pick an issue that is interesting to you. You'll be spending a lot of time researching and writing this paper. So it is important for you to choose a topic that you find interesting from the start. Test your argument. Find a peer (preferably one that holds an oppositional view) to discuss your argument with. This process will help you refine your thinking and develop new ideas to support your judgment. Keep your audience in mind. An important aspect of writing an argumentative essay is understanding your audience. Are you writing the paper for a class, in which case your audience is your professor and your classmates? Or perhaps you are writing it for a presentation to a larger group of people. Regardless, you must think about where your audience is coming from in order to lead them to your desired outcome. People's backgrounds and experiences often influence how they will react to views different from their own, so it is helpful for you to be knowledgeable about these factors. Understand the rhetorical situation. It is essential that you understand all of the factors in the situation surrounding your issue. All rhetorical situations contain five basic elements: the text (in your case, the essay), the author (in this case, you), the audience, the purpose or purposes of the communication, and the setting. Structuring Your Argument Create a catchy title. Developing a creative, original title is a fantastic opportunity to hook your reader into wanting to reading more of your paper before they even get to the introduction. A good title will act as a "preview" for what your paper will be about. Many titles for academic papers come in two parts, separated by a colon. The first part is often a catchy hook that involves a pun on your topic or an impactful quote, and the second part is usually a sentence that sums up or provides details about your argument. Come up with a thesis statement. Your thesis statement will be a concise idea that sums up your view on the issue. The thesis usually appears at the end of the introduction paragraph. Having this idea in mind early on in the reading process will help guide your reader through the rest of the paper. You can refer Essay writing service to get help. Avoid the standard three-part thesis often taught to beginning writers. This format is constricting and limits the shape your ideas can take to being contained in three basic body paragraphs. Write an introduction. This section should briefly explain the essay topic and include relevant background information to familiarize the reader with the topic. As previously mentioned, your thesis statement should appear at the end of the introduction. Write the body of the paper. Carefully present information that supports both your argument and opposition. Acknowledge evidence that supports the opposition, but utilize powerful evidence to assert your claim. Write a conclusion. The aim of this section is to reassert your argument and persuade the audience to support your claim. Try to connect the essay topic to the interests and values of the audience. Be sure to review your main points and restate your thesis. But make sure not to introduce any new information in the conclusion so that you can effectively wrap up what you've already said.

Writing an argumentative paper means you are picking a controversial topic and writing to prove your viewpoint. ---- Here are two different example. A political example:Recent judicial ruling illustrate that every couple whether they are marrying the opposite sex or the same sex has every right to do so. It is time to inscribe gay couples rights to marriage in the constitution. A literary example:Jostein Gaarder's "Sophie's World" Jostein's Gaarder's "Sophie's Workd" illustrate teacher's inaptitude to teach effectively by manifesting a year's worth of history lessons in a single exciting novel. ---- The standard practice for writing any essay is the five paragraph essay.  1: Introductory ParagraphYou need a hook sentence, two or three at most. Then you briefly write the idea of your essay. Your last sentence should be like one of my examples, creating a sentence tying your whole essay together. 2: Detail Paragraph 3: Detail Paragraph 4: Detail Paragraph 5: Conclusion ParagraphThis might be the hardest paragraph to write. You do not want to add anything to your essay here. If it is a new fact or detail do not put it here! You only want to reword what your essay was about and tie in you description paragraphs together.  Since you are writing an argumentative essay you should write two description paragraphs that prove your view. The third paragraph should be proving the other side of the argument wrong.  Example: You are writing about legalizing gay rights in the constitution. 1: Stastical facts. Facts in general. Etc.2: An important quote. Answer why it should be legal. 3: Prove your point against a counter argument. People who want it to stay illegal are saying that the next thing you know people will want to marry animals if the US allows gay marriage. Tell us why that isn't true or if it's a good point have a counter argument to theirs.  --- Never use a fact or a quote without a reason. The next sentence that follows a fact or quote must directly relate that information to your argument. Never use information that does not directly prove your point. You always want to pick a fact or quote by someone or an organization that is important in that specific topic. Generally you don't want to use any more than 3 quotes at most. Be concise. Don't wander off your topic. You don't nenessarily have to write five paragraphs but it is simply a standard practice for those who are learning. You should only break the standard if you already mastered the skill. Or you are at risk to totally butchering your essay. Lastly, argumentative essays are written ALWAYS in the third person view point. Never write in first person or second person if it's essay for a teacher unless specified to do so. For example, do not use the words "I" "She" "he" "your" "they" Unless those words are in a quote. Good luck. --EJ@JenkinsWritings

There are, the three parts to an argumentative essay are: Introduction; Body; Conclusion. The introduction to an argumentative essay must be like any other introduction. Punchy and attention-grabbing. While keeping true to the issue at hand. An introductory paragraph that flows naturally into the main body of the text is essential to maintain the reader’s interest. Aside from grabbing the reader’s attention, the introduction also offers background information on the issue to be discussed. However, the most important element of this paragraph is, no doubt, the Thesis Statement. Let’s take the concept of a Thesis Statement and break it down, because it is single-handedly the most important part of the essay writing process. What is a Thesis Statement? You probably have opinions on a lot of things. From the most trivial things, like the colour or shape of new cars, to more sensitive issues like animal testing, the death penalty, and so on. Some of these opinions will be more subjective than others, according to your background, upbringing, financial or social position, etc. But the main takeaway here is that these are your opinions and views on the matter. Your opinion or view on a particular subject is the Thesis Statement. It is a one-sentence statement that lets the reader know your interpretation of the subject being discussed. Think of the Thesis Statement as a one-sentence summary of the argument you’re about to make in your essay. It is your interpretation of the subject, not the subject itself. Let’s take an example of a perfectly workable introduction for an argumentative essay, including a Thesis Statement, to make your writing life just a little bit easier. In fact, we’ll give a bad and a good example of a Thesis Statement, so you can see the contrast between the two. Bad example Imagine you’re writing an argumentative essay about, say, the internet. Specifically, how the internet has improved the lives of so many people. A bad example of Thesis Statement related to this would be: The lives of many people worldwide have seen a great improvement due to the internet. Now, this is bad, right? Not only is this sentence vague and imprecise, but it is also very lazily written with passive voice all over the place. Furthermore, it raises a lot of questions: How was this achieved? Whose lives, are we talking? About exactly? Good example Consider this instead: The advent of the internet heralded a new era of worldwide unity, enabling instant, real-time communication with anyone, almost anywhere on the planet. Better? Right.

How To Write An Argumentative Essay Do you remember the time when you did a lot of research to convince your parents why they should get you an expensive car? That’s pretty much what you have to do in an argumentative essay. During your academic years, you have to master the art of composing stellar essays. The professor of your college or university might ask you to write an argumentative essay. If you want to score good grades, you should know how to write one. This blog can help you understand how to write an argumentative essay that fetches desired grades. What is an Argumentative Essay? While writing an argumentative essay, the writer needs to pick a topic or an issue and take a particular stand on it. Following this, he/she needs to find out relevant information and evidence to support the position he/she has taken. In this essay, you need to make a clear, specific, and reasonable argument and back it up with the help of proper evidence and information. Your main aim is to persuade the readers to believe in the claim you are making. Are Argumentative Essays and Persuasive Essays the same? Many students often get confused when they try to comprehend the difference between a persuasive essay and an argumentative essay. Some might believe that these two types of essays are the same. However, persuasive and argumentative essays differ from each other in more ways than one. You must know the difference so that you do not write a flawed essay. Establish need for the argument you intend to make with a statement that seems counterintuitive or which demonstrates a recent large change. Back this up with strong statistics from a reputable source. Make at least three argumentative statements concerning the topics you’ve broached. Finish with a thesis statement that describes exactly what you intend to demonstrate with your paper. As for the rest, discuss each of your three (or more) argumentative statements in their own section, in the same order they appeared in your introduction. Finish the paper by summarizing your arguments, again in the same order, along with a summary of the material you’ve provided to support them. I also used to finish papers with another strong argument tying the three main arguments together. Also, try to anticipate how your arguments will be attacked, and compensate for this: play devil’s advocate. Finally, don’t fill the paper with quotes, paraphrase wherever you can, and only quote sources that say things in a way that you could never improve upon. Also, I would caution against beginning your paper with a quote, because people who do this tend not to focus on what is being said as much as the name recognition of who is saying it. This is innately counter-intuitive, because the simple fact that someone is widely-known does not mean they are an expert in the field they are commenting on. For example, Jeff Bezos and Jack Ma routinely answer questions on a ridiculously wide variety of topics, and because they are internationally well-known and respected ecommerce billionaires, people listen to them. However, if they are being asked about anything other than ecommerce, I’d take what they have to say with at least a small grain of salt.

Original question was on finding a topic for an argumentative essay, not on how to write one. I do have a comment on the revised question. If you are in high school or in your first year of college, the teacher assigning something as important as an argumentative essay should be spending a class or two — maybe more — on instructing you. A teacher should have, and probably does have, lesson plans on essay preparation, at least as handouts. The fundamentals of thesis statement, organizational structure, honest use of sources, and acceptable documentation should be presented in class. After Freshman (college) year, you should be on your own, but presumptions about your readiness to write fact-based essays seem unfair, given the diversity of backgrounds in most college freshman classrooms. Original inquiry: finding a topic for an argumentative essay It depends. Some argumentative essays can be written on topics within your own range of experience, such as advocating a change in the drinking age from 21 to 19 or advocating limits on high school Advanced Placement courses, often being paid for by increased property taxes. Other topics might require thorough research, like making a prediction about increases in drug-related violence as an effect of cutting drug supply. I think argumentative papers on “unintended consequences” are very compelling. Raising the drinking age encourages binge drinking; bad publicity about for-profit fundraising has hurt charitable organizations; cutting the drug supply invites violence. Be careful. Do the do-able. Once, a student was working on a paper espousing the merits of “safe tanning.” She couldn’t find any corroborating sources beyond a couple of glamour magazine and had to abandon her paper.

Hi! As a student, I’ve had to write a lot of argumentative essays. Here’s what I do to get A’s on my papers. Don’t go with the usual introduction. Your english prof is going to have to read how many dozens of papers and I’m sure s/he doesn’t want to read a similar introduction in every one. Although it is tempting, steer far away from the usual “This is the book title and author, brief summary of argument/plot, thesis”. I would recommend finding a unique point/personal anecdote that also can be incorporated into your essay. For example, let’s say I am writing a paper about dogs being the best pets. I might say something along the lines of: “My dog, Blue, is an Australian Shepherd. He and I have been best friends for the sum total of seven years (49 for him). Though he can be a handful sometimes, he has fully convinced me that dogs are the best pets.”. And then you can go on with your thesis/rest of introduction. My other big tip would be don’t do the ‘fun-fact’ introduction. Please do not start your essay with “Source A demonstrates that ___% of people prefer dogs over any other creature” or something like that. Though it’s an opener that a lot of people are taught to work with, it oftentimes shows an inexperienced writer. Make sure you clearly introduce what side you are arguing. Don’t waffle. Don’t sit on the fence. Take a firm stand and stick with that through the rest of your paper. If you are qualifying (showing the good and bad of both sides) make sure you still take a stance. A qualifying paper is not a qualifying paper if you do not take a side. Aim for clarity in your argument and a good thesis statement and I’d say that you’re good to go! Best of luck in your endeavor!

To be a good one, an argumentative essay must include details to make the target audience see the issues from your perspective. These details are the following: • A hooking topicChoose a few issues that spark conflicting viewpoints. Make sure to pick the topic that you’re interested in. Create a list of points for both sides of your argument. As you shape your argument, tell your readers why your point of view is logical and reasonable. Later you’ll use them as your evidence. Finally, choose your side of the argument and ensure you can support the chosen point of view. • Strong evidence Choose solid arguments for both sides. No need to go dramatic here – just give strong facts and clear examples that back up your stance. Find examples that demonstrate how your argument impacts people, events, or the world, as well as give stats on your topic. If possible, interview professionals on your topic to come up with a compelling argument. • Properly structured textAn argument essay includes the intro, the body, and the conclusion. The first paragraph should introduce the topic, give some background info, and include the thesis statement. The latter is your position on the chosen topic. The body is the core of your argument. Give more details about the two sides of your argument and provide the strongest points of the topic counter-side. Once you describe the “other” side, give your own point of view together with evidence to prove your position is correct. Use other studies, stats, stories, and so on to discredit the other position and prove you’re right.• Conclusion Use conclusion to sum up your points and reinforce with your target audience why your side is the most rational one. Keep away from emotional language and fake evidence.

Clearly state your position. Don't agree with the opposing viewpoint at any point. Provide at least three concrete examples to support your position. Recognize that there are those who might disagree because […], then explain what they have wrong or have overlooked in their opposition. Write a conclusion that doesn't restate everything you just said, but that reinforces your position and general reasoning. This should take 5–6 paragraphs. Avoid writing “in my opinion “ and similar phrases, and state everything as fact for a stronger argument. “In my opinion “ allows that it is only your and only an opinion and weakens your position.

In the Rogerian Argument, lead with a clear understanding of your opponent’s argument. Then that other stuff (note that the Rogerian argument is not an argument to win with, Dr. Rogers was under the idea that we could reach a compromise. ) I recommend studying all three, then blend to suit your writing style.

An argumentative essay presupposes one or more opposing points of view.  If you already know the general direction of your essay, your next step is to unearth all the opposing points of view and dispassionately record their points of support.  Review these points of support and look at the points of support for your own position.  At this stage, lists of points, you can decide whether your point of view can stand the rebuttals from the other sides.   If so, write a section detailing and supporting your position, then draft rebuttals to all the significant opposing points of view you've found. Then you'll decide on a sequence of events.  Sometimes it's useful to start out with the opposition, eviscerating each point in turn, then saying, "Here's the correct point of view."  There are as many strategies for sequences as there are raisins in a bakery. Without specific data from the OP, this is about as far as I can go.

Imagine you’re telling a person they’re wrong in a civil, long-winded way that they could not refute if they tried, and start with the formal version of an ‘excuse me, you’re wrong’. Your essay body is ‘these are all the reasons why you’re wrong’, and the conclusion is ‘so therefore you are in fact very wrong: let me just briefly remind you why exactly you are an idiot’. The introduction should include a very short answer to the question and a sneaky peak of what you’ll be looking into (imagine the start of a documentary in which they say, “I’ll be travelling to such and such places, meeting a llama and finding out the meaning of true happiness” or something like that). The middle should have about three paragraphs in order of how strong the arguments are. You should always include in each of these paragraphs a very good argument for the other side of the debate just so you can tear it apart, and make sure to add references (if you’re writing an academic essay) just to show that you’re clever and all the professionals agree with you too. Then the conclusion should include a ‘so you see, this is why I think this’ as a summary of the essay at the end. And there you have a good essay. A good idea if you have a word limit is to roughly give each paragraph a word limit of its own, just so you don’t stray too far from the original word limit.
